options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to critically think about the design of the internet and how to implement web design through HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

I learned how to code basic websites and a browser extension. The main skill I would say I learned in this class was how to think like a coder, which for me meant thinking logically through the problems and hurdles I might encounter while attempting to code a functional website.

HTML/CSS, Javascript (almost always with jQuery), Github Pages, alternative web hosting, CSS animations and timers, Bookmarklet and Chrome extension development, web accessibility, inspecting/development tools, and a lot of other interactive design techniques.

I learned a lot about web development; the exercises and various assignments honestly leave you with a decent skillset for many things. For example, we learned how to create an animation on a webpage so that you could have, for example, something slowly change color over time or move across the screen.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The class has a lot of structure and projects that are dedicated to each skill, which helps a lot when it comes to beginners trying to sort through what code can do. The time we spent familiarizing ourselves with coding platforms, commands, and functions was very helpful. Additionally, Rosa is a great instructor who is always willing to spend time helping anyone understand any technical part of any assignment. (Also, the guest speakers are fantastic). 
Weaknesses: I would say that this class is not the most productive for beginners. It's theoretically meant to be for anyone but a large portion of people already have substantial coding experience, which makes it easy for more inexperienced coders to feel inadequate or feel like we're falling behind. That said, Rosa does her best to get everyone up to speed every class.

Flexible projects, great feedback from peers and professor, thoughtful readings and guests, workshops to help people without technical background. Class Are.na was very well-organized and extremely useful for gathering influences. Wish there was more room to showcase process (Are.na of updates) and give feedback to peers outside of class, especially because the set-up didn't always make it possible to interface with everyone in the already small class

I think a strength is the fact that it can be either more or less rigorous depending on how much time you have to dedicate, i.e. it's very flexible due to you being able to come up with your own ideas for most of the projects, although they all follow a general form of some general concept learned in the class such that you get to learn that specific concept and keep it in your toolset from then on.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Since this class was a coding class, I don't feel like we lost out on much instruction since in person, we would have been spending most of class time on our computers regardless.
I feel that virtual learning works just fine for a class such as this.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would! It's a great class to learn about coding from a more artistic perspective, which is extremely helpful for art majors. Just a word of caution to the more inexperienced, you will have to do a lot of reading on documentation on your own to understand what is going on.

Yes! If you have little background with the web, to think more artfully and poetically about the internet's potential; if you have no background at all, you'll get all the technical foundations you need to make websites. It balances the technical and creative wonderfully. If you came in with more background knowledge, definitely press yourself to make technically strong and thoughtful pieces  there are few other opportunities for you to do so at Yale, if any.
Yes; for those interested in web development at all it's great. I honestly learned a lot. And the professor also asks about what things we WANT to learn.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Screensharing notes on various web-development scripting language, class peer sharing of example websites and lexicon, peer sharing of our own ideas created, great exercises and prompts that spanned far and wide in the field of creating websites
